H0.text: Hydrosphere and biosphere interact and result in the formation of mountains.

H1.text: Troposphere and ionosphere are the two areas of Earth that interact to result in the formation of mountains when mountains are formed.

H2.text: The hydrosphere and lithosphere interact to form mountains.

H3.text: The asthenosphere and lithosphere interact and result in the formation of mountains when mountains are formed.

A4.text: The addition of water lowers the melting point of the mantle material above the subducting slab, causing it to melt. The magma that results typically leads to volcanism.

A5.text: At zones of ocean-to-continent subduction mountain ranges form, e.g. the Andes, the Cascade Range.

A6.text: Continental crust is a tertiary crust, formed at subduction zones through recycling of subducted secondary (oceanic) crust.
